docs.title: Dotfiles Documentation
docs.text:
Welcome to the documentation for my chezmoi-powered cross-platform dotfiles.

This site provides a deeper, structured explanation of how the repository works, how to customize it, and how scripts, templates, themes, and configuration files fit together.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This project uses chezmoi to manage configurations for:

  • Windows
  • macOS
  • Linux

The dotfiles are structured to be idempotent, portable, templatized, and data-driven.

docs.title: Configuration Data (.chezmoidata + .chezmoi.json.tmpl)
docs.text: This repository uses data-driven configuration, meaning the contents of .chezmoidata/ define how templates are generated.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
home/.chezmoidata/
├── apps.yaml
├── themes.yaml
└── vscode-profiles.yaml

docs.title: apps.yaml — Application Lists
docs.text:
Defines which apps to install for each OS.

Example:

windows:
  packages:
    - Microsoft.PowerShell
    - Git.Git

darwin:
  brews:
    - git
    - fish

Used by run_onchange_02-install-apps scripts for each platform.

docs.title: themes.yaml — Theme Definition
docs.text:
Defines reusable theme variables, e.g.:

theme: "dark"

colors:
  primary: "#3B82F6"
  background: "#0F0F0F"
  text: "#E5E5E5"

Used in: - VS Code templates - Terminal themes - Oh My Posh config - Any file requiring color definitions

See the Themes page for details.

docs.title: vscode-profiles.yaml
docs.text:
Suggested structure:

profiles:
  - name: "Personal"
    settings_file: "personal-settings.json"
    extensions:
      - ms-python.python
      - esbenp.prettier-vscode

This will allow your VS Code generator to: - create per-profile config directories - merge base settings + per-profile settings - install profile-specific extensions

docs.title: .chezmoi.json.tmpl — Machine Variables
docs.text:
This file sets derived configuration values that other templates rely on.

Example:

{
  "os": "{{ .chezmoi.os }}",
  "username": "{{ .chezmoi.username }}",
  "homedir": "{{ .chezmoi.homeDir }}"
}

You can also add machine-specific flags, such as:

"workMachine": {{ eq .hostname "WORK-LAPTOP" }},
"gpu": "{{ .cpu.gpu | default "none" }}"

docs.title: Using Data in Templates
docs.text:
Data inside .chezmoidata/ is available via:

{{ .data.apps }}
{{ .data.themes }}

The JSON from .chezmoi.json.tmpl becomes part of:

{{ . }}

during template execution.

docs.title: Automation Scripts (.chezmoiscripts)
docs.text:
Chezmoi supports run_once, run_onchange, and run_before scripts that automate system setup. This repository organizes these scripts by platform:

home/.chezmoiscripts/
├── Darwin/
└── Windows/

docs.title: run_once_*.sh / .ps1
docs.text:
Runs only once, after chezmoi init --apply. Used for tasks that should never repeat, such as:

  • Installing Homebrew or Windows package manager
  • Initial machine bootstrap
  • Cloning personal/work repos

docs.title: run_onchange_*.sh / .ps1
docs.text:
Runs whenever the script file changes. Useful for:

  • App installation lists
  • VS Code extension installation
  • Machine-specific system updates

docs.title: run_before_*.sh
docs.text:
Runs before files are applied. Ideal for:

  • Bootstrapping package managers
  • Installing dependencies required for generating certain templates

docs.title: macOS Scripts
docs.text:
Examples:

  • run_once_before_01-install-brew.sh Installs Homebrew if missing.

  • run_onchange_02-install-mac-apps.sh.tmpl Installs apps defined in .chezmoidata/apps.yaml.

  • Repo cloning scripts run_once_after_04_clone-personal-repos.sh.tmpl

docs.title: Windows Scripts
docs.text:
Examples:

  • run_once_before_01-install-package-manager.ps1.tmpl Bootstraps Winget / package manager.

  • run_onchange_02-install-apps.ps1.tmpl Installs apps declared in .chezmoidata/apps.yaml.

  • Terminal and shell setup run_once_after_04-setup-terminal.ps1.tmpl

docs.title: Adding Your Own Scripts
docs.text:
Just place your script under:

home/.chezmoiscripts//_*.sh

Chezmoi will automatically detect and execute it during the apply phase

docs.title: Templates (.chezmoitemplates)
docs.text:
Chezmoi templates allow dynamic generation of files using:

  • Go template syntax
  • Functions provided by chezmoi
  • Custom helper functions defined in template files
  • Data from .chezmoidata/*

docs.title: Template Directory Structure
docs.text:
home/.chezmoitemplates/
├── elevate-powershell
├── theme-colors
├── vscode-keybindings
└── vscode-settings

yaml Copy code

Each file defines reusable template fragments or functions.

docs.title: theme-colors
docs.text:
Provides helper functions for working with theme colors defined in:

home/.chezmoidata/themes.yaml

yaml Copy code

Includes helpers such as:

  • hexToRGB
  • rgbToHex
  • Shade/opacity helpers (optional depending on your implementation)

docs.title: vscode-settings and vscode-keybindings
docs.text:
These templates unify:

  • Shared base settings
  • Per-profile settings
  • OS-specific overrides

Used to generate:

~/AppData/Roaming/Code/User/settings.json ~/AppData/Roaming/Code/User/keybindings.json

yaml Copy code

And their macOS equivalents.

docs.title: elevate-powershell
docs.text: Contains logic for running elevated (Administrator) PowerShell tasks during script execution.

docs.title: Using Templates
docs.text:
Any file ending in .tmpl under home/ is treated as a template.

You can call templates using:

{{ template "vscode-settings" . }}

docs.title: Creating New Templates
docs.text: Templates are ideal for: - OS-specific file content - Reused settings (e.g., proxies, secrets prompts) - Shared JSON/YAML structures - Re-usable helper functions (math, strings, color transforms)

docs.title: Theme System
docs.text:
This dotfiles setup includes a data-driven theme system built from:

  • themes.yaml — defines theme colors
  • theme-colors template — provides helper functions for color manipulation

docs.title: themes.yaml
docs.text:
Example:

active: "gruvbox"

themes:
  gruvbox:
    primary: "#fabd2f"
    background: "#1d2021"
    text: "#ebdbb2"

  nord:
    primary: "#88C0D0"
    background: "#2E3440"
    text: "#ECEFF4"

You can add: - accents - borders - opacity variants - RGB arrays - semantic color names

docs.title: theme-colors Template
docs.text:
Provides functions such as: - hexToRGB - rgbToHex - shade/darken/lighten - color extraction utilities - reusable color structures for JSON/YAML templates

Example usage in a VS Code settings template:

"activityBar.background": "{{ themeColor "background" }}",
"activityBar.foreground": "{{ themeColor "text" }}",
"button.background": "{{ themeColor "primary" }}",

docs.title: Using Themes in Other Templates
docs.text:
You access the active theme via:

{{ $theme := index .data.themes.themes .data.themes.active }}

Then access colors:

{{ $theme.primary }}

Or use helper functions:

{{ colorHex "primary" }}
{{ hexToRGB $theme.primary }}

docs.title: Where Themes Are Used
docs.text:
• VS Code
  • Windows Terminal
  • Oh My Posh
  • Clink
  • Shell prompts
  • JSON/YAML-based config files
  • Any file that supports colors

docs.title: Visual Studio Code Integration
docs.text:
VS Code setup in this dotfiles repo is fully automated and templated, including:

  • settings
  • keybindings
  • extensions
  • profiles
  • OS-specific variations

docs.title: File Structure
docs.text:
home/
└── AppData/Roaming/Code/User/
├── settings.json.tmpl
└── keybindings.json.tmpl

home/.chezmoitemplates/
├── vscode-settings
└── vscode-keybindings

home/.chezmoidata/
└── vscode-profiles.yaml

docs.title: How Settings Are Generated
docs.text:
1. A shared base settings file is defined inside:
.chezmoitemplates/vscode-settings
  1. Additional configurations can be layered via:
  2. per-profile settings
  3. OS-specific checks
  4. theme colors

Example template:

{
    "editor.fontFamily": "JetBrains Mono",
    "workbench.colorCustomizations": {
        "activityBar.background": "{{ themeColor "primary" }}"
    }
}

docs.title: Extensions Installation
docs.text:
Extensions are declared in:

home/vscode-extensions.txt

Installed via: - macOS: run_onchange_03-install-vscode-extensions.sh.tmpl - Windows: run_onchange_03-install-vscode-extensions.ps1.tmpl

docs.title: Profiles
docs.text: Once vscode-profiles.yaml is added, you’ll be able to: - generate per-profile folders - merge base + profile settings - auto-install profile-specific extensions
